    Highlights

    •
    Construction of a high-resolution Hi-C map of macaque fetal brain
    •
    Cross-species 3D genome analyses uncover human-specific chromatin structures
    •
    The subplate lamina shows human-specific regulatory changes during corticogenesis
    •
    The human-specific loop regulating EPHA7 affects neuron dendrite development

    Summary

    Elucidating the regulatory mechanisms of human brain evolution is essential to understanding human cognition and mental disorders. We generated multi-omics profiles and constructed a high-resolution map of 3D genome architecture of rhesus macaque during corticogenesis. By comparing the 3D genomes of human, macaque, and mouse brains, we identified many human-specific chromatin structure changes, including 499 topologically associating domains (TADs) and 1,266 chromatin loops. The human-specific loops are significantly enriched in enhancer-enhancer interactions, and the regulated genes show human-specific expression changes in the subplate, a transient zone of the developing brain critical for neural circuit formation and plasticity. Notably, many human-specific sequence changes are located in the human-specific TAD boundaries and loop anchors, which may generate new transcription factor binding sites and chromatin structures in human. Collectively, the presented data highlight the value of comparative 3D genome analyses in dissecting the regulatory mechanisms of brain development and evolution.

    Graphical Abstract

    Keywords

    1. brain
    2. chromatin structure
    3. TAD

    10. EPHA7

Hence, it is feasible to hypothesize that the human-specific changes of chromatin structure may lead to gene regulation alterations and eventually contribute to the unique human brain phenotypes. To test this hypothesis, we need to generate brain 3D genome data of NHPs at key developmental stages in order to identify the human-specific gene regulatory changes. In theory, as the closest relative of human, chimpanzee would be the ideal NHP species to study (Waterson et al., 2005
    97.
    Waterson, R.H. ∙ Lander, E.S. ∙ Wilson, R.K., Chimpanzee Sequencing and Analysis Consortium
    Initial sequence of the chimpanzee genome and comparison with the human genome
    Nature. 2005; 437:69-87
    Crossref
    Scopus (1553)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). However, it is extremely difficult to obtain chimpanzee fetal brain samples for 3D genome experiments. Alternatively, as the most widely used NHP species, macaque is phylogenetically close to human (∼7% sequence divergence), and it is relatively easy to obtain brain samples at different developmental stages, making it a suitable model for exploring human brain evolution at 3D genome level.
    Here, we collected brain tissues of Chinese rhesus macaque (Macaca mulatta) at mid-gestation, and constructed a high-resolution 3D genome map, which provides valuable basis for further comparative 3D genomic analysis. Through multi-omics evolutionary analyses among human, rhesus macaque, and mouse, we identified many human-specific chromatin structure changes including topologically associating domains (TADs) and loops. We also studied the genomic features and functional enrichment of the human-specific TADs and loops to shed new light on the genetic basis of human brain development and evolution.

    Results

    Generation of a high-resolution 3D genome map of rhesus macaque during corticogenesis

    We sampled three macaque fetal brains at mid-gestation (E84), the time of neurogenesis peak during development. We dissected cerebral cortex into two major zones: (1) cortex plate (CP), consisting primarily of post-mitotic neurons, and (2) germinal zone (GZ), consisting primarily of neural progenitors (Figure 1A; STAR methods). To reveal the regulatory landscape of the developing macaque cortex, we constructed high-resolution genome-wide chromatin interaction maps using Hi-C. We also mapped gene expression (RNA sequencing [RNA-seq]), DNase I hypersensitive sites (DNase-seq), and CTCF occupancy (CTCF chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing [ChIP-seq]). We validated the accuracy of zone dissection by checking the expression of the known marker genes for neural progenitors (SOX2, PAX6, and FOXG1) and neurons (FEZF2, SYP, and NEUROD1) (Figure 1B).
    Using Hi-C 2.0 (Belaghzal et al., 2017
    2.
    Belaghzal, H. ∙ Dekker, J. ∙ Gibcus, J.H.
    Hi-C 2.0: An optimized Hi-C procedure for high-resolution genome-wide mapping of chromosome conformation
    Methods. 2017; 123:56-65
    Crossref
    Scopus (90)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), we sequenced ∼8 billion paired-end reads and generated nearly 5 billion unique mapped contacts in total (Table S1). The biological and technical replicates are highly correlated (Pearson’s correlation R ≥ 0.95) (Figures S1A and S1B), and we therefore merged the data by zone type for downstream analysis. We validated contact quality of the Hi-C data by cis/trans interaction ratio and distance-dependent interaction frequency decay (Figure S1C; Table S1). We reached an ultra-deep resolution of 1.5 kilobase pairs (kb) (Table S1; STAR methods), which enables us to explore macaque 3D genome structure at different scales, including compartments, TADs, and loops (Figure 1C).
    Most of the A/B compartments are conserved between CP and GZ, and the ratio (3.6%–3.8%) of switched compartments is consistent with previous findings in human fetal brains (CP versus GZ: 3.78%) (Won et al., 2016
    99.
    Won, H. ∙ de la Torre-Ubieta, L. ∙ Stein, J.L. ...
    Chromosome conformation elucidates regulatory relationships in developing human brain
    Nature. 2016; 538:523-527
    Crossref
    Scopus (199)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) (Figure S1D). We identified a total of 1,977 and 2,265 TADs for CP and GZ, respectively, among which 64.4% are shared between them (Figure S1E), and the numbers of the identified TADs in macaque is similar to the reported numbers of TADs in the human fetal brain (Won et al., 2016
    99.
    Won, H. ∙ de la Torre-Ubieta, L. ∙ Stein, J.L. ...
    Chromosome conformation elucidates regulatory relationships in developing human brain
    Nature. 2016; 538:523-527
    Crossref
    Scopus (199)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Because the resolution of the published human fetal brain Hi-C data was only 10 kb (Won et al., 2016
    99.
    Won, H. ∙ de la Torre-Ubieta, L. ∙ Stein, J.L. ...
    Chromosome conformation elucidates regulatory relationships in developing human brain
    Nature. 2016; 538:523-527
    Crossref
    Scopus (199)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), for cross-species comparison, we called loops in macaque with the same resolution using the HICCUPS pipeline (Rao et al., 2014
    77.
    Rao, S.S. ∙ Huntley, M.H. ∙ Durand, N.C. ...
    A 3D map of the human genome at kilobase resolution reveals principles of chromatin looping
    Cell. 2014; 159:1665-1680
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (2411)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) (STAR methods). In total, we identified 8,399 and 15,048 loops in CP and GZ, respectively (Figure S1F). The 3C experiments show that 86.6% (26/30) of the loops can be validated, suggesting our Hi-C results are reliable (Figure S1G; Table S2). There are 8,179 (54.4%) loops shared between CP and GZ (Figure S1F), and the smaller number of loops (∼44% reduction) in CP relative to GZ is consistent with the reported reduction (∼40% to 50% decrease) of loops in human neurons relative to neural progenitor cells (Rajarajan et al., 2018
    75.
    Rajarajan, P. ∙ Borrman, T. ∙ Liao, W. ...
    Neuron-specific signatures in the chromosomal connectome associated with schizophrenia risk
    Science. 2018; 362:eaat4311
    Crossref
    Scopus (53)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). As expected, the zone-specific loops are associated with differential gene expression (Figure S1H). For example, we observed zone-specific chromatin interactions at SOX2 (highly expressed in GZ) and BHLHE22 (highly expressed in CP), respectively (Figures 1D and S1I).
    To show that the identified loops using our ultra-deep contact maps are informative in detecting regulatory events in the genome, as a proof of principle, we checked interactions between two putative enhancers and the promoter of FOXP2 (Figure 1E), a well-known gene that plays an important role in human speech and language development (Lai et al., 2000

    To assess the penetrance of the detected loops around FOXP2, we performed 3D-DNA FISH using the brain tissue sections of fetal monkeys (STAR methods), and the results are consistent with the Hi-C data that the loop regulating FOXP2 are present in both CP (69.0%, 49/71) and GZ (76.7%, 66/86) at similar frequency (Fisher’s exact test, p = 0.284) (Figures 1F, 1G, S1K, and S1L; Table S2). These cases indicate that our Hi-C data can effectively capture regulatory events during corticogenesis.
    We next performed cross-species Hi-C analyses at multiple scales, which allows us to characterize human-specific patterns in 3D genome organization.

    Cross-species analyses uncover human-specific TADs

    TADs are fundamental regulatory chromatin structures and are largely conserved across tissues and species (Dixon et al., 2012

Here, we characterize the evolutionary dynamics of TADs by comparative brain Hi-C across human, macaque, and mouse (outgroup). We define the shared TADs among the three species as the conserved TADs, and those only gained or lost in human as the human-specific TADs (hsTADs) (STAR methods). We found 499 hsTADs, including 410 human gained TADs (hgTADs) and 89 human lost TADs (hlTADs) (Figure S2C). The medium size of hgTADs is 640 kb, smaller than the conserved TADs (900 kb) (Figure S2C), consistent with the published data showing a large size of the conserved TADs by comparing human, gibbon, and other mammalian species (Lazar et al., 2018
    51.
    Lazar, N.H. ∙ Nevonen, K.A. ∙ O’Connell, B. ...

    Sexton, T. ∙ Yaffe, E. ∙ Kenigsberg, E. ...

We saw similar species-specific TAD size patterns in macaque and mouse (Figure S2C).
    We then compared the TAD boundaries among species (STAR methods). The results show that ∼55% (n = 1,513) of the TADs boundaries are conserved across species, and ∼14% (n = 385) of the TAD boundaries are the hgTAD boundaries (Figures 2A and 2B; Table S3).
    We further explored the features of the conserved and the hgTAD boundaries. The conserved TAD boundaries have stronger insulation than the hgTAD boundaries (Figures 2C and S2D). Although most of the conserved and the hgTADs boundaries are enriched with CTCF binding, the enrichment levels are lower for the hgTAD boundaries (63%) than the conserved TAD boundaries (77%), indicating that the hgTAD boundaries are less CTCF dependent than the conserved TAD boundaries (Figure 2D). We also found the hgTAD boundaries showed weaker CTCF ChIP-seq signals than the conserved boundaries in neural cells (Song et al., 2019

    Song, M. ∙ Yang, X. ∙ Ren, X. ...

    ) and found that the conserved TAD boundaries had higher conservation ratio across tissues and cell types, while the hgTAD boundaries were more tissue and cell-type-specific (Figures 2E and S2F). Collectively, through cross-species comparison, we were able to identify human-specific TADs, especially the hgTADs, which showed distinct features in view of size, CTCF binding strength, and tissue/cell specificity, an implication functional specialization of these newly evolved TADs during human brain evolution.

    The hgTAD boundaries are enriched with evolutionarily young transposable elements

    Previously, it was reported that the mammalian interspersed repeats (MIRs), a conserved family of transposable elements (TEs), can serve as insulators within TAD boundaries in a CTCF-independent manner (Wang et al., 2015
    96.
    Wang, J. ∙ Vicente-García, C. ∙ Seruggia, D. ...

We found the conserved TAD boundaries were enriched for evolutionarily old TEs, including MIR, LINE-2 (L2), Charlie, and MaLR (Figure S2G). By contrast, the hgTAD boundaries are enriched in evolutionarily young TEs, and four TE families are slightly enriched, including Alu, LINE-1 (L1), human endogenous retrovirus subfamily 1, and K (ERV1 and ERVK) (Figures 2F and S2G). In particular, compared to the conserved boundaries, the hgTAD boundaries are significantly enriched in AluY, the youngest Alu elements in primates (Kapitonov and Jurka, 1996

    The human-specific chromatin loops are enriched in enhancer-enhancer interactions

    Compared to TADs, chromatin loops are more dynamic across developmental stages and may affect gene expression (Bonev et al., 2017
    5.
    Bonev, B. ∙ Mendelson Cohen, N. ∙ Szabo, Q. ...
    Multiscale 3D Genome Rewiring during Mouse Neural Development
    Cell. 2017; 171:557-572.e24
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (361)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We identified loops in the three species at 10 kb resolution using the HICCUPS pipeline (Rao et al., 2014
    77.
    Rao, S.S. ∙ Huntley, M.H. ∙ Durand, N.C. ...
    A 3D map of the human genome at kilobase resolution reveals principles of chromatin looping
    Cell. 2014; 159:1665-1680
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (2411)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) (Figure S3A; STAR methods). Aggregating peak analysis (APA) demonstrated the accuracy of loop calling (Figure S3B). This was further supported by the epigenetic features of loops (Figure S3C).
    Next, we compared loops across species using the merged CP and GZ loop profiles so that the species-specific rather than the zone-specific changes can be detected. In total, we identified 1,904 conserved loops (ConsLs) among the three species and 1,266 human-specific loops (HSLs) (Figures 3A and 3B; Table S4), and these loops were validated by APA (Figures 3A and S3D). In general, the lengths of HSLs and the macaque-specific loops are significantly smaller than that of ConsLs (Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, p < 2.2 × 10−16), while the pattern is opposite in mouse (Figure S3E). Similar to the result of the TAD boundaries, the species-specific loop anchors are less enriched in CTCF ChIP-seq signals than the ConsL anchors (Figure S3F).
    To explore the function of the different loop categories, we integrated them with human fetal brain H3K4me1 signals (Kundaje et al., 2015) which reflect enhancer potentials. Remarkably, HSLs are significantly enriched for enhancers compared to ConsLs (Fisher’s exact test, p < 2.2 × 10−16), while no such enrichment is detected for promoters (Figures 3C and 3D). Almost 80% of the HSL anchors contain at least one enhancer, compared to less than 60% for the ConsL anchors (Figure 3D). In terms of loop types, the enhancer-promoter interactions account for only ∼27% of HSLs, and nearly 40% of HSLs are enhancer-enhancer interactions, which is a significant enrichment compared to ConsLs (Fisher’s exact test, p < 2.2 × 10−16) (Figure 3E). The enrichment of enhancer-enhancer interactions is not seen in the macaque/mouse specific loops (Figures S3G and S3H).
    Enhancer-enhancer interactions are implicated in gene control by forming enhancer cliques or spatially interaction hubs to regulate gene expression (Mumbach et al., 2017

    One remarkable case showing the regulatory feature of the human-specific interactions involves the AUTS2 (autism susceptibility candidate 2) gene. Strikingly, there is a complex interaction hub regulating AUTS2 in the human fetal brain. The hub contains 14 enhancers and more than half of the loops in the hub are human-specific (Figures 3H, 3I, and S3I). Two human enhancers (hs1425 and hs658) showed midbrain and neural-tube-specific expression in mouse embryos (Visel et al., 2007
    95.
    Visel, A. ∙ Minovitsky, S. ∙ Dubchak, I. ...

    ) (Figure S3J). By contrast, there is only one loop detected in macaque and three in mouse within the orthologous region (Figures 3I and S3I). Consistently, in the CP zone, the expression of AUTS2 is significantly higher in human than in macaque (Figure S3K). In addition, compared with macaque, human has more CTCF-binding sites in this region, some of which are close to the HSL anchors (Figure 3I). The difference in CTCF-binding sites may be responsible for the chromatin structure and gene expression difference between human and macaque brains.

    Genes associated with HSLs are preferentially expressed in the subplate lamina of the developing brain

    We defined 1,411 and 1,079 target genes for ConsLs and HSLs, respectively, by combining target genes of direct promoter-enhancer or promoter-promoter loops and target genes of enhancer-enhancer loops through contact communities (Table S4; STAR methods). We found that the HSL target genes tend to be more upregulated in human compared to macaque than the ConsL target genes and the target genes of the macaque-specific loops (Figures S4A and S4B), an indication of gene regulatory changes associated with HSLs.
    Gene regulation usually works in a tissue and cell-type-specific manner. We analyzed enrichment of target genes in different laminae using the microarray data from the laser-micro-dissected human fetal brain (Miller et al., 2014
    62.
    Miller, J.A. ∙ Ding, S.L. ∙ Sunkin, S.M. ...
    Transcriptional landscape of the prenatal human brain
    Nature. 2014; 508:199-206
    Crossref
    Scopus (550)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Surprisingly, the HSL target genes are significantly enriched in inner cortical plate (CPi) and subplate (SP) compared to the ConsL target genes (Figure 4A). For example, NR4A2 and TMEM178A, the two SP preferentially expressed genes, are regulated by HSLs (Table S4). We confirmed this pattern by checking the published human fetal brain single-cell RNA-seq data (Nowakowski et al., 2017
    67.
    Nowakowski, T.J. ∙ Bhaduri, A. ∙ Pollen, A.A. ...
    Spatiotemporal gene expression trajectories reveal developmental hierarchies of the human cortex

    Scopus (220)

    ). Interestingly, the HSL target genes are enriched in excitatory projection neurons from the cortical deep layer, and this enrichment is the most prominent in the excitatory neurons of SP (Figure 4B). In contrast, the target genes of the macaque specific loops are not enriched in any lamina (Figure S4C). We also checked the target genes of the human-macaque shared loops (not present in mouse), and we saw a significant enrichment in ventricular zone (VZ) (Figure S4C), consistent with the view that the primate brains have an enlarged neural progenitor pool compared with rodents (Lui et al., 2011
    57.
    Lui, J.H. ∙ Hansen, D.V. ∙ Kriegstein, A.R.

    Full Text

    ). In addition, the target genes of the human-macaque shared loops are slightly enriched in excitatory SP neurons, but statistically not significant (Figure S4D).
    We then explored the function of the HSL target genes. First, we performed gene co-expression module enrichment analysis using the modules identified in the previous report (Miller et al., 2014
    62.
    Miller, J.A. ∙ Ding, S.L. ∙ Sunkin, S.M. ...

The most enriched module is M16, which is enriched in SP, and the function of M16 is related to synaptic transmission and synaptogenesis (Figure 4C), consistent with the known function of SP (Judaš et al., 2013
    35.
    Judaš, M. ∙ Sedmak, G. ∙ Kostović, I.

    Dean, C. ∙ Dresbach, T.

    ). The other four enriched modules are involved in regulation of transcription (M6), long-term depression (M26), DNA replication (M34) and cell cycle (M38) (Figure S4F). These data suggest HSLs regulate genes in several functional modules, especially synapse development of the SP neurons.
    Next, we performed Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis, and the results show that the HSL target genes are related to biological processes such as axon guidance, neuron migration, and synapse assembly (Figures S4G and S4H; Table S4). Axon guidance plays an important role in shaping neuron circuits (Stoeckli, 2018
    92.
    Stoeckli, E.T.
    Understanding axon guidance: are we nearly there yet?
    Development. 2018; 145:dev151415

    ). Many genes involved in the axon guidance pathway are regulated by HSLs, especially genes encoding key guidance molecules (ephrins and semaphorins) such as EPHA7 and SEMA3A (Figure 4D). Altogether, these results further support our hypothesis that the human-specific chromatin interactions play a key role in human cortex development, especially the human-specific changes in the SP lamina during early neural circuit development.
    One promising HSL target gene is EPHA7. It is SP-preferentially expressed and upregulated in humans compared with macaque (Figures 4E–4G), and can influence cortical dendritic development and spine maturation (Clifford et al., 2014
    8.
    Clifford, M.A. ∙ Athar, W. ∙ Leonard, C.E. ...
    EphA7 signaling guides cortical dendritic development and spine maturation
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2014; 111:4994-4999
    Crossref
    Scopus (0)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We identified a human-specific loop showing enhancer-promoter interaction in the human fetal brain (Figure 4H). Concordantly, the enhancer activity in macaque is much weaker than that in human (Figure 4H). Furthermore, the enhancer in HSL anchor is brain-specific compared with other human fetal tissues (Kundaje et al., 2015
    45.
    Kundaje, A. ∙ Meuleman, W. ∙ Ernst, J. ..., Roadmap Epigenomics Consortium
    Integrative analysis of 111 reference human epigenomes
    Nature. 2015; 518:317-330
    Crossref
    Scopus (2646)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) (Figures 5A and 5B). We used a luciferase assay to validate the enhancer activity among species, the results show that the enhancer activity in human is significantly higher than those of chimpanzee and macaque (Figure 5C). We compared the enhancer sequences among species and found six evolutionarily conserved sites that only changed in the human lineage (Figure 5D). These six human-specific single nucleotide changes (SNCs) formed new potential transcription factor (TF) binding sites in human (Figure 5D). Therefore, we speculate that the new TF binding sites may induce human-specific chromatin interaction changes, leading to expression divergence between human and macaque (Figure 4G).
    To explore the functional role of the enhancer regulating human EPHA7, we disturbed the enhancer sequence using the CRISPR-Cas9 method (Figure 5E). Three deletions were introduced within the enhancer locus, resulting in a 50% reduction of EPHA7 expression in neurons differentiated from human NPCs (Figures 5F and 5G). Next, we evaluated whether the disturbed enhancer affects neuron dendrite development. We observed significantly longer dendrite length in neurons with the disturbed enhancer compared with the controls (Figures 5H and 5I). These data suggest that the human-specific enhancer of the SP-preferentially expressed EPHA7 gene plays an important role in early neural circuit development which may contribute to the unique traits of the human brain.

    Google Scholar
    ). To explore how TFs may interact with the human brain 3D genome and regulate SP cell fate decision, we performed motif binding site analysis in the open chromatin regions of the HSL and ConsL anchors using the ATAC-seq profile from CP (STAR methods). As expected, the architectural proteins such as CTCF and CTCFL fall in the top of the TF list (Figure S5A). The percentage of binding in anchors and the significance of enrichment show distinctive changes for some of the motifs between HSL and ConsL anchors (Figures 6A and 6B). Architectural proteins (CTCF and CTCFL) are less enriched in the HSL anchors compared to the ConsL ones, consistent with our previous finding that HSLs are less CTCF dependent than ConsLs using CTCF ChIP-seq (Figures 6B and S3F). In contrast, the neural cell-type-related TFs are more enriched in HSLs compared to ConsLs. Notably, we found three NFI factors (NFIA, NFIC, and NFIX) enriched in the HSL anchors, which can repress self-renewal of neural stem cells and activate the expression of genes associated with neuronal and astrocyte differentiation (Harris et al., 2015
    25.
    Harris, L. ∙ Genovesi, L.A. ∙ Gronostajski, R.M. ...
    Nuclear factor one transcription factors: Divergent functions in developmental versus adult stem cell populations
    Dev. Dyn. 2015; 244:227-238
    Crossref
    Scopus (33)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We obtained similar results in motif binding analysis when using the ATAC-seq profile from GZ (Figure S5B) and different motif enrichment methods (Figure S5C).
    Next, we intend to know whether part of these HSL-preferred bindings is sequence driven (i.e., containing SNCs). We checked the enrichment in the human-specific SNCs for TFs showing HSL-binding preference (Figure S5D). Approximately 65% (11 out of 17) of these TFs with HSL-binding preference are significantly enriched in the human-specific SNCs (Figure 6C) (false discovery rate [FDR] <0.001), such as TGIF1, EOMES, and TBR1 (Figure 6D). The human-fixed SNC enrichment ratio in the TF set with HSL-binding preference (65%) is much higher than all TFs (30.3%) and the TF set without binding preference (33.7%) (Figure S5E, Fisher’s exact test, p = 0.0056 and p = 0.016, respectively). One example of the human-specific SNC that generates new binding site is the enhancer regulating AUTS2 (Figure 3K) that contains one human-specific SNC resulting in a new TGIF1 binding site in human (Figures 6E and 6F). TGIF1 has an important role in regulating neuronal morphogenesis (Nakashima et al., 2018
    64.
    Nakashima, H. ∙ Tsujimura, K. ∙ Irie, K. ...
    Canonical TGF-β Signaling Negatively Regulates Neuronal Morphogenesis through TGIF/Smad Complex-Mediated CRMP2 Suppression
    J. Neurosci. 2018; 38:4791-4810
    Crossref
    Scopus (16)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    We then asked how many HSL target genes are regulated by these TFs showing enrichment difference between ConsLs and HSLs. We define target genes of TFs by combining motif binding analysis of promoter and gene-TF co-expression (STAR methods). We generated TF-target gene networks for the TFs with HSL-binding preference (Figure 6G). In fact, some of the TFs are the HSL target genes themselves such as TBR1, NFIA, NFIX, and TCF4, which display different lamina-specificity in the expression data. TBR1 and NFIA are SP-enriched, while NEUROG1/2, EOMES, and TGIF1 are germinal layers enriched (Figure 6H). Remarkably, TBR1 has the largest number of target genes and most of them show CPi/SP enrichment (Figures 6G and 6I). A former study has revealed that TBR1 gene loss affects SP formation and thalamocortical connectivity (Hevner et al., 2001
    30.
    Hevner, R.F. ∙ Shi, L. ∙ Justice, N. ...
    Tbr1 regulates differentiation of the preplate and layer 6
    Neuron. 2001; 29:353-366
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (612)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), suggesting that TBR1 might be one of the key TFs regulating SP neuron specialization.
    Collectively, we show that TBR1 and NFIA are candidate TFs mediating expression of the HSL-regulated gene to determine the fate of human SP neurons. Our results also echo a recent study, in which they demonstrated that NFIA can act as FOXP2 coactivators to promote chromatin decondensation and regulate the maturation of early excitatory SP neurons (Hickey et al., 2019
    31.
    Hickey, S.L. ∙ Berto, S. ∙ Konopka, G.
    Chromatin Decondensation by FOXP2 Promotes Human Neuron Maturation and Expression of Neurodevelopmental Disease Genes
    Cell Rep. 2019; 27:1699-1711
    Full Text

    ).

    Genomic basis of the human-specific chromatin structure changes

    Former studies have shown that sequence changes in the genome may cause chromatin structural changes and pathogenic phenotypes (Lupiáñez et al., 2015
    58.
    Lupiáñez, D.G. ∙ Kraft, K. ∙ Heinrich, V. ...
    Disruptions of topological chromatin domains cause pathogenic rewiring of gene-enhancer interactions

    ). Thus, we proceed to explore the sequence basis of the detected human-specific chromatin changes. The results suggesting that the HSL anchors are less conserved than the ConsL anchors when compared with chimpanzee and macaque (Figure S6A), and the between-species sequence divergence may contribute to HSL formation. We also checked whether HARs (human accelerated regions) (Pollard et al., 2006
    73.
    Pollard, K.S. ∙ Salama, S.R. ∙ Lambert, N. ...
    An RNA gene expressed during cortical development evolved rapidly in humans

    ) are enriched in HSLs. The results indicate that the HSL anchors are significantly enriched for HARs (compared to random regions, permutation test, p = 1.07 × 10−38, and compared to ConsL anchors, Fisher’s exact test, p = 0.04) (Figure 7A). In particular, we identified 45 HARs located within the HSL anchors including enhancers or promoters (Figure 7B). In some cases, both anchors of a HSL contain HARs, and other cases show one HAR associated with multiple HSLs (Figure 7B). Interestingly, we found one HAR (ANC584) located within an HSL anchor on human chromosome 12 (Figure 7C). Both ChIP-seq (H3K4me1) and ATAC-seq data suggest ANC584 overlaps with an enhancer and show higher activity in human compared to macaque. The Hi-C data indicate that ANC584 may regulate the SP-preferentially expressed gene-SOX5 (Figure 7C), providing an example of how HARs may cause human-specific regulatory changes through spatial chromatin interaction in the SP laminae of the developing brain.
    Next, we investigated the role of human-specific structural variants (SVs) in the formation of the human specific chromatin structure. We obtained the human-specific SV profile (human versus great apes) from the published data (Dennis et al., 2017

    ). We checked the relationship between the human-specific SVs and HSL. We found 165 human-specific SVs overlapped with 161 HSL anchors (Figure 7D). We investigated if the human-specific SVs cause changes at the TAD level. We found 60 human-specific SVs located in 48 hgTAD boundaries and 74 human-specific SVs located in 57 hlTAD boundaries (Figure 7D). There are no significant differences of gene expression around the SV-overlapped hgTAD and hlTAD boundaries compared with the background, and no neural-related functions are enriched (Figures S6B and S6C).     Discussion

    We constructed an ultra-deep 3D genome map of macaque fetal brain and carried out comparative evolutionary analysis among human, rhesus macaque, and mouse at 3D genome level. We uncovered a prominent feature of HSLs (i.e., the enrichment of enhancer-enhancer interactions). Together with the enhancer-promoter interactions, they form regulatory communities. A former study found loops that appear during cell differentiation were more enriched in enhancer-enhancer interactions than static loops (Phanstiel et al., 2017
    71.
    Phanstiel, D.H. ∙ Van Bortle, K. ∙ Spacek, D. ...
    Static and Dynamic DNA Loops form AP-1-Bound Activation Hubs during Macrophage Development
    Mol. Cell. 2017; 67:1037-1048.e6
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (85)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Our data suggest that, not only cell-type-specific loops but also species-specific loops may directly mediate enhancer-enhancer interactions. Compared with promoters, enhancers are spatiotemporal specific and may change constantly during development (Nord et al., 2013
    65.
    Nord, A.S. ∙ Blow, M.J. ∙ Attanasio, C. ...
    Rapid and pervasive changes in genome-wide enhancer usage during mammalian development
    Cell. 2013; 155:1521-1531
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (202)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The precise control of gene expression may require more sophisticated enhancer-enhancer interactions in a tissue or cell-type-specific manner during human brain development. Additionally, genes regulated by multiple enhancers may have an enlarged expression spectrum because turning on and off one enhancer may have limited effect on gene expression, while the expression change can be quite large when two or more enhancers are involved (Kieffer-Kwon et al., 2013
    40.
    Kieffer-Kwon, K.R. ∙ Tang, Z. ∙ Mathe, E. ...
    Interactome maps of mouse gene regulatory domains reveal basic principles of transcriptional regulation
    Cell. 2013; 155:1507-1520
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (214)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Hence, this multi-enhancer regulation is likely an acquired mechanism for the fine-tuning of human brain development.
    SP, the largest transient zone expanded in the human fetal brain, is approximately four times thicker than the cortical plate during mid-gestation (Kostovic and Molliver, 1974
    42.
    Kostovic, I. ∙ Molliver, M.E.
    New interpretation of laminar development of cerebral cortex synaptogenesis in different layers of neopallium in human fetus
    Anat. Rec. 1974; 178:395
    Google Scholar
    ; Kostovic and Rakic, 1990
    43.
    Kostovic, I. ∙ Rakic, P.
    Developmental history of the transient subplate zone in the visual and somatosensory cortex of the macaque monkey and human brain
    J. Comp. Neurol. 1990; 297:441-470
    Crossref
    Scopus (675)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). SP has an important role in establishment of thalamocortical connection and contributes to cortical lamination through migration to cortical deep layer (Kanold et al., 2003
    37.
    Kanold, P.O. ∙ Kara, P. ∙ Reid, R.C. ...
    Role of subplate neurons in functional maturation of visual cortical columns
    Science. 2003; 301:521-525
    Crossref
    Scopus (213)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Ozair et al., 2018
    68.
    Ozair, M.Z. ∙ Kirst, C. ∙ van den Berg, B.L. ...
    hPSC Modeling Reveals that Fate Selection of Cortical Deep Projection Neurons Occurs in the Subplate
    Cell Stem Cell. 2018; 23:60-73.e6
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (22)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). A recent study reported that human accelerated conserved noncoding sequences regulate genes enriched in SP, which might be involved in human specific neurodevelopment (Miller et al., 2014
    62.
    Miller, J.A. ∙ Ding, S.L. ∙ Sunkin, S.M. ...
    Transcriptional landscape of the prenatal human brain
    Nature. 2014; 508:199-206
    Crossref
    Scopus (550)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We show that HSLs regulate genes mainly enriched in the SP lamina, implying that the SP neurons are important in neural circuit formation and plasticity during human brain development.
    We investigated the role of HARs and human-specific SVs in forming human-specific chromatin structures. However, different from the former study showing that 42% HARs interact with the flanking gene promoters (Doan et al., 2016
    16.
    Doan, R.N. ∙ Bae, B.I. ∙ Cubelos, B. ..., Homozygosity Mapping Consortium for Autism
    Mutations in Human Accelerated Regions Disrupt Cognition and Social Behavior
    Cell. 2016; 167:341-354.e12
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (94)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), we observe that HARs may occur within the enhancer-enhancer mediated HSL anchors, suggesting that HARs can work in different ways to regulate gene expression in the developing human brain. On the other hand, although the chromatin landscape constrains SVs within humans and across primate evolution (Fudenberg and Pollard, 2019
    20.
    Fudenberg, G. ∙ Pollard, K.S.
    Chromatin features constrain structural variation across evolutionary timescales
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2019; 116:2175-2180
    Crossref
    Scopus (25)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), we identified 134 human-specific SVs located in the human-specific TAD boundaries. Importantly, we found that the SVs overlapped with the hlTAD boundaries may contribute to the detected regulatory changes during SP development. To fully understand the contribution of the human-specific genetic changes (such as HARs and SVs), more omics and functional experiments are needed.
    We show that four TE families are enriched in the hgTAD boundaries, especially the two young TE subfamilies (AluY and L1PA), which may contribute to hgTAD formation and influence gene expression during human brain development. Currently, how TEs regulate TAD boundary formation is still in question. Two possible mechanisms have been proposed: (1) the transcriptional activity of TEs can decide TAD boundary formation (Zhang et al., 2019
    103.
    Zhang, Y. ∙ Li, T. ∙ Preissl, S. ...
    Transcriptionally active HERV-H retrotransposons demarcate topologically associating domains in human pluripotent stem cells
    Nat. Genet. 2019; 51:1380-1388
    Crossref
    Scopus (42)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ); and (2) other proteins can compete with CTCF in binding TEs to form TAD boundaries (Kaaij et al., 2019
    36.
    Kaaij, L.J.T. ∙ Mohn, F. ∙ van der Weide, R.H. ...
    The ChAHP Complex Counteracts Chromatin Looping at CTCF Sites that Emerged from SINE Expansions in Mouse
    Cell. 2019; 178:1437-1451.e14
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (22)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Kaaij et al. (2019)
    36.
    Kaaij, L.J.T. ∙ Mohn, F. ∙ van der Weide, R.H. ...
    The ChAHP Complex Counteracts Chromatin Looping at CTCF Sites that Emerged from SINE Expansions in Mouse
    Cell. 2019; 178:1437-1451.e14
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (22)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
     reported the ChAHP complex (CHD4, ADNP, HP1) can bind to SINE B2 transposable elements and compete with CTCF in forming TAD boundaries in mouse. We therefore speculate that those TEs enriched in the hgTAD boundaries may provide binding sites for neural-development-related TFs and promote formation of the hgTAD boundaries.
    It should be noted that we used liftover to get the corresponding locations of TAD boundaries and loop anchors when performing cross-species analyses. Therefore, the non-syntenic regions were mostly excluded in this process, which may give an inflated picture of the overall conservation of 3D genome architecture. We find most human TADs and loops are located in the syntenic regions (Figures S7A and S7B), and the conservation levels of TADs and loops in the syntenic regions are slightly overestimated due to the low conservation of the non-syntenic regions (Figures S7C and S7D). The non-syntenic TADs and loops are associated with different types of genome structural changes during evolution such as translocations, inversions, and large gaps (Figure S7E). We presented examples to show how these non-syntenic regions affect the evolution of human chromatin structures (Figures S7F and S7G). More accurate genome landscape (such as a high-quality macaque reference genome) (He et al., 2019
    27.
    He, Y. ∙ Luo, X. ∙ Zhou, B. ...
    Long-read assembly of the Chinese rhesus macaque genome and identification of ape-specific structural variants
    Nat. Commun. 2019; 10:4233
    Crossref
    Scopus (8)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) would be needed to better understand the relationship between non-syntenic regions and 3D genome architectures.
    In summary, we generated a high-resolution 3D genome profile of NHP during corticogenesis, which allowed us to reveal the human-specific 3D genome changes through cross-species analyses. Comparative 3D genome analyses are powerful approaches in deciphering the regulatory mechanisms of brain development and evolution.

    Data and code availability

    The sequencing data generated in this study are available at the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE163177; accession number: GSE163177), and the Genome Sequence Achieve (GSA, https://bigd.big.ac.cn/gsa/; accession number: CRA001934).

    Experimental model and subject details

    Rhesus macaque fetal brain samples

    Fetal brain of rhesus macaque was obtained from Kunming Primate Research Center, Kunming Institute of Zoology. All animal procedures were conducted following the international standards, and were approved in advance by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of Kunming Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (Approval No: SMKX-2017021).
    We collected three fetal brains of rhesus macaque (Macaca mulatta) at mid-gestation (E84), and the fronto-parietal cortex was dissected. The brains were kept in ice-cold DMEM/F12 (GIBCO, 11320033) during dissection. Under a dissection microscope, the coronal sections were divided into two major zones: CP - consisting primarily of post-mitotic neurons, including the marginal zone (MZ), cortical plate (CP) and subplate (SP) and GZ - consisting primarily of neural progenitors, containing intermediate zone (IZ), outer subventricular zone (OSVZ), inner subventricular zone (ISVZ) and ventricular zone (VZ). The dissected tissues were further cut into small pieces and digested in TrypLE Express Enzyme (GIBCO, 12604021). The tissues were vortexed and kept at 37°C for 10 min. The cell suspension was pipetted further to disperse into single cells and centrifuged at 300 g for 5 mins to obtain cell pellets. The digestion medium was carefully removed, the cells were washed twice with PBS. Finally, the cell pellets were re-suspended in 1ml DMEM medium (GIBCO, 12430054) and kept on ice. The cells were divided into two parts: one was crosslinked by formaldehyde for Hi-C, DNase-seq and ChIP-seq, and the other was immediately frozen for RNA-seq. Cells were fixed by final concentration of 1% formaldehyde (Sigma-Aldrich, F1635), mixed for 10 mins at room temperature. Fixation was quenched using 2.5 M glycine at room temperature for 5 mins and immediately centrifuged at 800 g for 10 mins. Supernatant was removed and frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80°C until further use.

    Neural cell lines

    Human neural progenitor cells (NPCs) induced from human iPSC were expanded by plating on Poly-L-ornithine (Sigma, P4957) and Laminin (GIBCO, 23017015) coated plates with proliferation media [Neurobasal media (GIBCO, 21103049), 1% N2 supplement (GIBCO, A1370701), 2% B27 (GIBCO, 17504044), 20 ng ml−1 basic fibroblast growth factor (GIBCO, 13256029) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin] following the published protocols (Gunhanlar et al., 2018
    23.
    Gunhanlar, N. ∙ Shpak, G. ∙ van der Kroeg, M. ...
    A simplified protocol for differentiation of electrophysiologically mature neuronal networks from human induced pluripotent stem cells
    Mol. Psychiatry. 2018; 23:1336-1344
    Crossref
    Scopus (65)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). For differentiation, NPCs were cultured in the differentiation media composed of Neurobasal, N2, B27, NEAA (Sigma, M7145), 1% Glutmax (Sigma, 3505061), 10 ng/ml BDNF (GIBCO, PHC7074) and 10 ng/ml GDNF (GIBCO, PHC7041), 1 μM Dibutyryl CAMP (Sigma, D0627), 200 μM ascorbic acid (Sigma, A5960) and 1% penicillin/ streptomycin. Half of the media was replaced by fresh medium every 3 days. All cells were incubated at 37°C and 5% CO2.

    Method details

    Hi-C library preparation

    Hi-C libraries were constructed based on the published Hi-C 2.0 protocol (Belaghzal et al., 2017
    2.
    Belaghzal, H. ∙ Dekker, J. ∙ Gibcus, J.H.
    Hi-C 2.0: An optimized Hi-C procedure for high-resolution genome-wide mapping of chromosome conformation
    Methods. 2017; 123:56-65
    Crossref
    Scopus (90)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Five million fixed cells were re-suspended in lysis buffer (final concentration of 10 mMTris, pH 8.0, 10 mM NaCl, 0.2% Igepal CA-630 and 1 × cOmplete protease inhibitors (Sigma-Aldrich, 11697498001) and incubated on ice for 10 mins. Removal of lysis buffer was done by centrifugation at 2500 g for 5 mins at 4°C, followed by removal of supernatant. The pellet was re-suspended in 342 μL 1 × NEBuffer 3.1, and incubated with 38 μL 10% SDS at 65°C for 10 mins. Next, 43 μL of 10% Triton X-100 was added to the Hi-C-tube to quench the SDS at 37°C for 15min. We then add 12 μL 10 × NEBuffer 3.1 and 400U DpnII (NEB, R0543), and mix gently to digest the chromatin overnight at 37°C on a rocking platform. On the next day, the DpnII restriction enzyme was inactivated at 65°C for 25 mins. Then, biotin-14-dATP (Life Technologies, 19524-016), dCTP, dGTP, dTTP and DNA polymerase I Kenow were added (NEB, M0210), and incubated at 23°C for 4 h. The digested chromatin was diluted and re-ligated by T4 DNA ligase (NEB, M0202), incubated at 16°C for 4 h, and shaken manually for three times. The chromatin products were de-cross-linked overnight by adding 30 μL proteinase K, and incubated at 65°C overnight. The DNAs were extracted and dissolved in 50ul 10 mMTris, pH 8.0. Then T4 DNA polymerase (NEB, M0203) was used to remove biotin from un-ligation ends for 4 hr at 20°C, and the enzymes were inactivated for 20 mins at 75°C. The DNAs were sheared to a size of 200-300 bp using Covaris M220. DNA size selection was conducted using AMpure XP magnetic beads (Beckman Coulter, A63881). Biotin pulldown was performed with Streptavidin T1 beads (Life Technologies, 65602). End repair, A adding, adaptor adding reaction, PCR amplification and DNA products size selection were performed sequentially. The libraries were sequenced by the Illumina PE150 paired-end sequencing platform.

    DNase-seq library preparation

    DNase-seq processing followed the published protocol with slight modifications for our samples (He et al., 2014
    26.
    He, H.H. ∙ Meyer, C.A. ∙ Hu, S.S. ...
    Refined DNase-seq protocol and data analysis reveals intrinsic bias in transcription factor footprint identification
    Nat. Methods. 2014; 11:73-78
    Crossref
    Scopus (129)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). One million fixed cells were re-suspended in 1 mL buffer A+ (15 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 15 mM NaCl, 60 mM KCl, 1 mM EDTA, pH 8.0, 0.5 mM EGTA, pH 8.0, 0.15mM Spermine, 0.5mM Spermidine, 1 x PIC 50 × 200ul, 1mM PMSF, 0.5mM DTT, 0.2% NP40), digested on ice for 10 minutes, and centrifuged at 2500 rpm for 3 mins. The supernatant was removed, and the pellet was re-suspended in 500ul 37°C pre-warmed 1x digestion buffer. 25U DNaseI (Roche, 4716728001) was added and inverted to mix, and incubated at 37°C for 5 mins. 500ul stop buffer was added (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 100 mM NaCl, 0.10% SDS, 100 mM EDTA, pH 8.0 with spermine, spermidine, and 2ul of RNase) to each reaction and mixed by inverting. The chromatin products were de-cross-linked overnight, and incubated at 65°C overnight. DNA extraction, end repair, A adding, adaptor adding reaction and PCR amplification were performed sequentially. The PCR products were run on a 2% agarose gel, the 180-500bp fragments were selected by gel cutting. The size selected DNAs were purified using QIAGEN Gel Purification Kit. The libraries were sequenced by the Illumina PE150 paired-end sequencing platform.

    CTCF ChIP-seq library preparation

    Five million fixed cells were re-suspended in cold cell lysis buffer (10mM Tris pH 8, 10mM NaCl, 0.2% NP-40, 1xEDTA-free Protease Inhibitors). Cells were lysed for 10 mins, washed once with cold PBS and re-suspended in 100ul per IP cold nuclei lysis buffer (50mM Tris pH8, 10mM EDTA, 1% SDS, 1xProtease Inhibitors). Nuclei were lysed for 15 mins at 4°C and then sonicated for 20 cycles using Bioruptor (Diagenode). After sonication, 5x volumes of IP dilution buffer (20mM Tris pH8, 2mM EDTA, 150mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 0.01% SDS, 1x protease inhibitors) was added, and chromatin was precleared using 25ul Protein A dynabeads (ThermoFisher, 10002D) / 1mL for 1hrs at 4°C with rotation. Beads were then washed once with 0.5% BSA in PBS, and added to the precleared chromatin and incubated overnight at 4°C with rotation. Beads were then washed once with cold IP wash buffer 1 (20mM Tris pH8, 2mM EDTA, 50mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 0.1% SDS), twice with high salt wash buffer (20mM Tris pH8, 2mM EDTA, 500mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100,0.1% SDS), once with cold IP wash buffer 2 (10mM Tris pH8,1mM EDTA,250mM LiCl,1% NP-40,1% sodium deoxycholate) and twice with cold TE buffer (1mM Tris pH8, 1mM EDTA). DNA extraction, end repair, A adding, adaptor adding reaction and PCR amplification were performed sequentially. The libraries were sequenced by the Illumina PE150 paired-end sequencing platform.

    RNA extraction and library preparation

    RNA was extracted from GZ and CP cells using the QIAGEN miRNeasy Mini Kit (QIAGEN, 217004). Concentration and purity were evaluated with a NanoDrop. 2 μg total RNA per sample was used as input material for the RNA sample preparation. Library preparation was completed using the VAHTS Total RNA-seq Library Prep Kit for Illumina (Vazyme, NR603-01) following the manufacturer’s recommendations. The libraries were sequenced by the Illumina PE150 paired-end sequencing platform.

    3D DNA-FISH

    Oligopaint libraries were designed using the OligoMiner pipeline (Beliveau et al., 2018
    3.
    Beliveau, B.J. ∙ Kishi, J.Y. ∙ Nir, G. ...
    OligoMiner provides a rapid, flexible environment for the design of genome-scale oligonucleotide in situ hybridization probes
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2018; 115:E2183-E2192
    Crossref
    Scopus (44)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We run OligoMiner on the rheMac8 reference genome with the “balance” parameter sets (36-41 nucleotide homology length) using LDM and kmerFilter. Probes were designed to target a 70 Kb region at a density of about 5.17 probes per kilobase (Table S2).
    Frozen fetal monkey brain was coronally sectioned at 8 μm. The tissues were fixed using 4% PFA for 10min at room temperature, washed with PBS for three times, then permeabilized with 1% Triton X-100 (Sigma, 10789704001) in PBS for 15min at room temperature and treated with 100ug/ml RNaseA at 37°C for 45 min. The slides were incubated in 0.5M HCl for 10 min at room temperature, washed with 2 × SSC (Thermo Fisher Scientific, AM9763), and treated with 0.01M HCl/0.0025% pepsin (Macklin, P6322-100 g) for 10min at 37°C. The pepsin was then inactivated by washing with 50mM Mgcl2/PBS for twice, and the slides were washed with 2 × SSC for three times, then incubated in 50% of Formamide (Sigma, S6639-1L) with 2 × SSC overnight at 4°C. In the next day, the cells were predenatured at 78°C for 10min and put into 70%, 90% and 100% cold ethanol for 2 min sequentially and then air-dried. The 1st probes were denatured at 86°C for 5min and put quickly on ice. Then the probes were loaded on slide areas with cells, and the slides were incubated at 86°C for 3min and put quickly on ice, hybridized at 42°C overnight in a dark and humidified chamber. In the next day, the slides were washed with 2 × SSC/0.1% Tri-tonX-100 for three times at 60°C. The 2st probes were added on the slides and incubated at room temperature for 1h. The slides were washed with 40% Formamide/2 × SSC one time and 30% Formamide/2 × SSC two times, mounted by ProLong Diamond Antifade Mountant with DAPI (ThermoFisher Scientific, P36966).

    Functional validation of the human EPHA7 enhancer

    We designed four sgRNAs to disturb the human EPHA7 enhancer using the guide RNA design tool CHOPCHOP (http://chopchop.cbu.uib.no/) (sgRNA1: CCCTAAATTCAGGAACTATT; sgRNA2: GGCTTGACTCAACTGACCAA; sgRNA3: TAGTTACTCTCTGCACAACC; sgRNA4: GCCAAATTCATGTCGTTTCC). sgRNAs were cloned into the pL-CRISPR.EFS.GFP (Addgene, 57818) or pL-CRISPR.EFS.tRFP (Addgene, 57819) plasmids (Heckl et al., 2014
    28.
    Heckl, D. ∙ Kowalczyk, M.S. ∙ Yudovich, D. ...
    Generation of mouse models of myeloid malignancy with combinatorial genetic lesions using CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing
    Nat. Biotechnol. 2014; 32:941-946
    Crossref
    Scopus (276)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Lenti-virus were produced using 293T cells and concentrated with Lenti-X Concentrator reagent (Takara, 631231). Human NPCs were cultured and infected with the concentrated virus, and in the next day, the virus was removed and replaced with fresh medium. Two days later, the NPCs were differentiated by replacing differentiation medium and cultured for two weeks. The dual GFP/tRFP positive cells were isolated by FACS for genome DNA and RNA extraction. The sgRNAs efficiency were validated by PCR amplification of the human EPHA7 enhancer locus and the expression of EPHA7 was quantified by qPCR. EPHA7-enhancer PCR Primers: forward- ACTAGGTTTCTTGGTGTTCATTCCC, reverse- TTGTACAGTCCCTCTATCACATGCA; qPCR primers: GAPDH forward- GTCTCCTCTGACTTCAACAGCG, GAPDH reverse: ACCACCCTGTTGCTG-TAGCCAA, EPHA7 forward- CTCGCAAGTGAGTGGAGTAATG, EPHA7 reverse- GTTGAGTAGGTCCGTTCCCTTTG.
    The differentiated neurons were fixed with 4% PFA, permeabilized with 0.3% Triton X-100, blocked with 10% BSA, and incubated with primary antibodies GFP (Abcam, ab13970, 1:1000) at 4°C overnight, then incubated with secondary antibodies at 25°C for 1 h, counterstained with DAPI. Each group was repeated with three replicates, and P values were calculated using t test.

    Luciferase assay

    Human SK-N-SH cells were cultured with basic growth media (DMEM, 10%FBS, 2 mM Glutamine and 1x Pen/Strep). The human EHAP7 enhancer and the orthologous chimpanzee and macaque sequences were cloned into the pGL3-promoter vector (Promega, E1761). 500 ng pGL3-EPHA7-promoter or pGL3-promoter and 20ng pRL-TK (Promega) were transfected into SK-N-SH cells in 24-well plates using lipofectamine 3000. After 48 hours, cells were washed for three times using PBS, and luciferase activity was measured by Dual Luferase Reporter System (Promega). Each group was repeated with six technical replicates. Firefly luciferase activity was normalized to Renilla luciferase activity. P values were calculated using t test.

    3C assay

    Five million cross-linked cells were re-suspended in lysis buffer and incubated on ice for 15 mins. Removal of lysis buffer was done by centrifugation at 2500 g for 5 mins at 4°C, followed by removal of supernatant. The pellet was re-suspended in 342 μL 1 × NEBuffer 3.1, and incubated with 38 μL 10% SDS at 65°C for 10 mins. Next, 43 μL of 10% Triton X-100 was added to the Hi-C-tube to quench the SDS at 37°C for 15min, then add 12 μL 10 × NEBuffer 3.1 and 400U DpnII (NEB, R0543), and mix gently to digest the chromatin overnight at 37°C on a rocking platform. In the next day, the DpnII re-striction enzyme was inactivated at 65°C for 25 mins. Then, re-ligated by T4 DNA ligase (NEB, M0202), incubated at 16°C for 4 h, and shaken manually for three times. The chromatin products were de-cross-linked overnight by adding 30 μL proteinase K, and incubated at 65°C overnight. Phenolic/chloroform was used to extract DNA. PCR and Sanger sequencing were carried out to confirm the long-range chromatin interaction. PCR primers are listed in Table S2.

    Hi-C data pre-process, matrix normalization and visualization

    Paired-end reads of the Hi-C libraries were pre-processed using HiC-Pro (V2.9.0) as described in the previous report (Servant et al., 2015
    82.
    Servant, N. ∙ Varoquaux, N. ∙ Lajoie, B.R. ...
    HiC-Pro: an optimized and flexible pipeline for Hi-C data processing
    Genome Biol. 2015; 16:259
    Crossref
    Scopus (432)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In brief, reads pairs were aligned to the reference genomes (hg19 for human, rheMac8 for macaque, and mm10 for mouse) in two steps. The first step aligns reads using bowtie2 end-to-end algorithm. The second step detect the ligation sites and the 5′ fraction of the reads were aligned back to the genome. Aligned read pairs were assigned to DpnII restriction fragments. Invalid pairs like dangling end were filtered out. The genome was divided into specific size bins, and valid pairs were counted per bins. We used 500 kb, 100 kb, 40 kb bin sizes to generate raw and ICE (iterative correction and eigenvector decomposition) (Imakaev et al., 2012
    34.
    Imakaev, M. ∙ Fudenberg, G. ∙ McCord, R.P. ...
    Iterative correction of Hi-C data reveals hallmarks of chromosome organization

    Crossref
    Scopus (527)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) normalized matrix. 500 kb matrix was used to identify compartments, 100 kb matrix was used to calculate Pearson correlation of replicates, and 40 kb matrix was used to define TAD boundaries. The valid pair files were transformed to .hic files which were ready for juicer (V1.11.04) (Durand et al., 2016
    18.
    Durand, N.C. ∙ Shamim, M.S. ∙ Machol, I. ...
    Juicer Provides a One-Click System for Analyzing Loop-Resolution Hi-C Experiments

    Definition and calculation of resolution

    we defined and calculated the Hi-C map resolution as described in Rao et al. (2014)
    77.
    Rao, S.S. ∙ Huntley, M.H. ∙ Durand, N.C. ...
    A 3D map of the human genome at kilobase resolution reveals principles of chromatin looping
    Cell. 2014; 159:1665-1680
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (2411)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    . The map resolution is defined as the smallest bin size where 80% of bins have at least 1,000 contact reads. The calculating scripts are from the published study
    (https://github.com/aidenlab/juicer/blob/master/misc/calculate_map_resolution.sh.).

    Compartments analysis

    We assigned A/B compartments as described in the previous study (Lieberman-Aiden et al., 2009
    55.
    Lieberman-Aiden, E. ∙ van Berkum, N.L. ∙ Williams, L. ...
    Comprehensive mapping of long-range interactions reveals folding principles of the human genome
    Science. 2009; 326:289-293
    Crossref
    Scopus (3659)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In brief, the expected contact frequency was calculated by the distance between the two loci. Pearson correlation matrix was calculated based on the observed/expected matrix. Principal component analysis was performed on the Pearson correlation matrix. The first principal component (PC1) was used to assign compartments. Eigenvalues with higher gene density was assigned as A compartment, otherwise assigned as B compartment.

    TAD calling

    We defined TAD boundaries by two methods: insulation score analysis and domain caller (Dixon et al., 2012
    15.
    Dixon, J.R. ∙ Selvaraj, S. ∙ Yue, F. ...
    Topological domains in mammalian genomes identified by analysis of chromatin interactions
    Nature. 2012; 485:376-380
    Crossref
    Scopus (3008)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Crane et al., 2015
    10.
    Crane, E. ∙ Bian, Q. ∙ McCord, R.P. ...
    Condensin-driven remodelling of X chromosome topology during dosage compensation
    Nature. 2015; 523:240-244
    Crossref
    Scopus (292)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). For insulation score analysis, local contact insulation score was calculated as described in the previous report. We calculated insulation score using 40 kb bin size and 800 kb sliding window size (average size of TAD). The insulation score was normalized by the mean of all bins per chromosome. Valleys along the normalized insulation score indicate the reduced Hi-C contact. The valleys were detected by the finding horizontal zero point of delta vector. We filtered the horizontal zero points at peaks. Boundaries with distance less than 40 kb were merged into one. For domain caller, we calculated directionality index in 40 kb bin size using 2 Mb window size. Then we inferred the true hidden directionality bias by hidden Markov model (HMM). Domains were inferred from the HMM state calls. Regions between TADs and less than 400 kb were defined as boundaries.

    Definition of insulation strength

    To test the insulation intensity of different types of boundaries, we defined insulation strength (see the illustration below). In brief, we calculated interactions within intra-TAD and inter-TAD 100 kb around a given boundary. Then we defined the ratio of (Iintra-TAD – Iinter-TAD) and (Iintra-TAD + Iinter-TAD) as insulation strength. Interactions in the diagonal were filtered out.
    Iinter−TAD⁢=Ia+Ib
    Iinter−TAD⁢=Ic
    insulationstrength=Iintra−TAD⁢−Iinter−TADIintra−TAD⁢+Iinter−TAD

    Definition of conserved and species-specific boundaries and TADs

    To compare boundaries across species, we liftOver (Hinrichs et al., 2006
    32.
    Hinrichs, A.S. ∙ Karolchik, D. ∙ Baertsch, R. ...
    The UCSC Genome Browser Database: update 2006
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2006; 34:D590-D598
    Crossref
    Scopus (559)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) macaque’s and mouse’s boundaries to the human reference genome (hg19). If distance of two boundaries was less than 80 kb (2 bins), these two boundaries are defined as conserved boundaries of two species (see the illustration below). The boundary conserved in three species was defined as species-conserved boundary. To select the most-likely distinct boundaries, we defined species-specific boundary as distance more than 200 kb (5 bins). TADs flanked by the conserved boundaries at both sides are defined as conserved TADs. TADs flanked by the species-specific boundaries at least one side are defined as species-specific TADs. For the data shown in figures, we merged boundaries called from different brain regions (CP and GZ) or cell types (CN and NPC) for each species.

    Overlap of TAD boundaries with repeat elements

    Repeat elements were downloaded from the UCSC Genome Browser (http://hgdownload.cse.ucsc.edu/goldenPath/hg19/database/rmsk.txt.gz). We calculated the density of repeat elements overlapped with Cons or HG TAD boundaries (numbers of repeat element per boundaries). Then we used t test to quantify the difference of repeat elements density between Cons and HG TAD boundaries.

    Loop calling

    We detected significantly enriched contact interactions using Hi-C computational Unbiased Peak Search (HiCCUPS) (V1.11.04) (Durand et al., 2016
    18.
    Durand, N.C. ∙ Shamim, M.S. ∙ Machol, I. ...
    Juicer Provides a One-Click System for Analyzing Loop-Resolution Hi-C Experiments
    Cell Syst. 2016; 3:95-98
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with default settings as described in the previous study (Rao et al., 2014
    77.
    Rao, S.S. ∙ Huntley, M.H. ∙ Durand, N.C. ...
    A 3D map of the human genome at kilobase resolution reveals principles of chromatin looping
    Cell. 2014; 159:1665-1680
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (2411)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In brief, fold change values quantifying enrichment of contact frequency compared to local background were calculated. Then we tested if the number of the observed contacts is significantly enriched. P value was Benjamini-Hochberg adjusted to correct for multiple tests. Pixels with enrichment in all local neighborhoods (donut, horizontal, vertical and lower right) were kept. Then cluster of nearby enriched pixels were analyzed using a greedy algorithm. To generate the maximum counts of reads, samples were merged for each brain zones. We detected loops at 10 kb resolution.

    Aggregated peak analysis

    To test the enrichment of the detected loops, we performed the aggregated peak analysis (APA) using juicer tools (V1.11.04) (Durand et al., 2016
    18.
    Durand, N.C. ∙ Shamim, M.S. ∙ Machol, I. ...
    Juicer Provides a One-Click System for Analyzing Loop-Resolution Hi-C Experiments
    Cell Syst. 2016; 3:95-98
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) as described in the previous study (Rao et al., 2014
    77.
    Rao, S.S. ∙ Huntley, M.H. ∙ Durand, N.C. ...
    A 3D map of the human genome at kilobase resolution reveals principles of chromatin looping
    Cell. 2014; 159:1665-1680
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (2411)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In brief, submatrices around peaks were taken from KR-normalized matrix and then summed. The APA matrix was plotted as the heatmap. APA score was calculated as ratio of number of reads in the center bin to average number of reads in the lower-left corner. APA score greater than 1 represents enrichment peak. Some APA scores labeled in figures were normalized by dividing all the submatrices by the mean value of the submatrix.

    Definition of conserved and species-specific loops

    Cross-species loop comparison was achieved by the following pipeline. For each species, loops obtained from different brain zones or cell types are combined to get a concatenate loop list. The coordinates for loop anchors on target genome were obtained from source genome using UCSC liftOver and only loops with both anchors that can map to a 5kb to 20kb region are retained. LiftOver and reciprocal liftOver have to be unique. Anchors that have more than 50% overlapped with source coordinates during reciprocal liftOver are retained. Then the mapped position of each loop anchor was aligned to the unit resolution interval with the highest degree of coincidence.
    For each mapped loop, two kinds of judgements were performed: the distance judgement which determines whether the mapped loop is located near any loop of target species and the enrichment judgement which determines whether the mapped loop still show signal enrichment in the Hi-C contact map of target species. The distance judgment is achieved by comparing the two-dimensional Euclidean distance between loops with some preset thresholds:
    𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑒<max⁡(𝑟⁢𝑎⁢𝑑⁢𝑖⁢𝑢⁢𝑠,min⁡(𝑟1×|𝑖−𝑗|,𝑟2))
    Here, the radius which is the output of HiCCUPS represents the surrounding area of corresponding target species loop and |𝑖−𝑗| represents the distance between two anchors of it, while 𝑟1 and 𝑟2 are relative distance coefficient and absolute distance threshold, respectively, which are preset parameters, and 0.2 and 20kb used for identifying conserved loops while 0.2 and 50kb used for finding species-specific loops.
    The enrichment judgement was performed to check whether the mapped loops showed signal enrichment over the local background. Matrices were normalized and the expected normalized contacts at each distance were calculated. For each mapped loop, we defined several local neighborhoods as described by Rao et al. (2014)
    77.
    Rao, S.S. ∙ Huntley, M.H. ∙ Durand, N.C. ...
    A 3D map of the human genome at kilobase resolution reveals principles of chromatin looping
    Cell. 2014; 159:1665-1680
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (2411)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    : donut, horizontal, vertical, and lower left. For each neighborhood, ratio of sum of the observed counts to sum of expected counts were calculated and then multiplied by the expected signal of the mapped loop, and this value is the estimation of expected contacts for the corresponding neighborhood. Then the fold-changes of observed contacts of mapped loop over the expected contacts of four kinds of neighborhoods are calculated separately. We calculated these four kinds of fold-changes for each enriched-pixel of target species and selected 20% quantiles of them to be thresholds. For example, when the target species is mouse, a mapped loop with fold-change of observed versus expected (horizontal and vertical) > 1.5, fold-change of observed versus expected (lower-left and donut) > 1.65, fold-change of observed versus expected (lower-left or donut) > 1.76 is considered as signal enriched. Otherwise, if all the fold-changes above are less than 1.3, the mapped loop is considered as no-enriched pixel. Combining the distance judgement and enrichment judgement, we can determine whether a mapped loop is species-conserved or species-specific in the following way: a mapped loop which is close enough to a loop of target species or has signal enrichment over local background will be considered as species-conserved; if it’s separated from all the loops of target species and determined as no-enriched pixel, it will be considered as species-specific. It should be noted that here we do not classify all the loops, but use different parameters when identifying conserved and species-specific loops to ensure that both loop sets are credible.

    GO enrichment analysis

    GO enrichment was performed on genes with promoter overlapped boundaries (20kb around) or loop anchors. Promoters were defined as upstream 2 kb and downstream 2kb of transcription start site (TSS). Biological process, cellular component and molecular function gene ontology were performed using DAVID (Dennis et al., 2003
    13.
    Dennis, Jr., G. ∙ Sherman, B.T. ∙ Hosack, D.A. ...

    ; Kundaje et al., 2015
    45.
    Kundaje, A. ∙ Meuleman, W. ∙ Ernst, J. ..., Roadmap Epigenomics Consortium

    ), and H3K4me1 peaks overlapped a promoter were filtered out. Enhancers of macaque were defined as regions with an H3K4me2 or H3K27ac peak of 12 PCW macaque frontal cortex from Reilly et al. (2015)
    78.
    Reilly, S.K. ∙ Yin, J. ∙ Ayoub, A.E. ...

    , and H3K4me1 peaks overlapped a promoter were filtered out.

    Motif enrichment analysis

    To find enriched motif for transcription factor binding sites in ATAC-Seq peaks (for human) or DNase-I Hypersensitivity (DNase) peaks (for macaque and mouse) which overlapped with loop anchors, we obtained motifs from JASPAR v2018 (Khan et al., 2018
    39.
    Khan, A. ∙ Fornes, O. ∙ Stigliani, A. ...
    JASPAR 2018: update of the open-access database of transcription factor binding profiles and its web framework
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2018; 46:D260-D266
    Crossref
    Scopus (568)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and known motifs from HOMER (V4.10) (Heinz et al., 2010
    29.
    Heinz, S. ∙ Benner, C. ∙ Spann, N. ...
    Simple combinations of lineage-determining transcription factors prime cis-regulatory elements required for macrophage and B cell identities
    Mol. Cell. 2010; 38:576-589
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (4333)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Sequences in the ATAC-Seq peaks or the DNase peaks were input for HOMER package motif finder algorithm findMotifGenome.pl. We used a random set of background regions chosen by HOMER. For the occurrence of motif, we used the FIMO (V5.0.2) (Grant et al., 2011
    22.
    Grant, C.E. ∙ Bailey, T.L. ∙ Noble, W.S.
    FIMO: scanning for occurrences of a given motif
    Bioinformatics. 2011; 27:1017-1018
    Crossref
    Scopus (1382)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with P value cutoff 10-4.

    Community detection

    We detected community as described in the previous report (Phanstiel et al., 2017
    71.
    Phanstiel, D.H. ∙ Van Bortle, K. ∙ Spacek, D. ...
    Static and Dynamic DNA Loops form AP-1-Bound Activation Hubs during Macrophage Development
    Mol. Cell. 2017; 67:1037-1048.e6
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (85)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). A non-directed network was generated from Hi-C interactions using igraph package (V1.2.4). Loop anchors were defined as nodes, and loops as edges. Community was detected by fastgreedy.community function from igraph with default settings. Protein-protein interaction network (STRING) community was detected in the same way.

    Lamina-specific and module-specific analysis

    We used mid-gestational human neocortical laminar gene expression data from the published study (Miller et al., 2014
    62.
    Miller, J.A. ∙ Ding, S.L. ∙ Sunkin, S.M. ...
    Transcriptional landscape of the prenatal human brain
    Nature. 2014; 508:199-206
    Crossref
    Scopus (550)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) to do lamina-specific and module-specific analysis. Lamina specificity was quantified as described in the previous study (Parikshak et al., 2013
    69.
    Parikshak, N.N. ∙ Luo, R. ∙ Zhang, A. ...
    Integrative functional genomic analyses implicate specific molecular pathways and circuits in autism
    Cell. 2013; 155:1008-1021
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (523)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In brief, specific expression of genes in a lamina was against to all other laminae, and t values of each gene per lamina were generated to quantify the expression specificity. Given a set of genes (such as all target genes regulated by HSLs), we quantified the skew of t value sets using whole genome genes as the background. We got z-scores and corresponding P values. We quantified module-specificity of a set of genes for 42 modules detected in the previous study (Miller et al., 2014
    62.
    Miller, J.A. ∙ Ding, S.L. ∙ Sunkin, S.M. ...
    Transcriptional landscape of the prenatal human brain
    Nature. 2014; 508:199-206
    Crossref
    Scopus (550)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We assigned enrichment of a set of genes by permutation test. We randomly selected the same number as given gene sets 10,000 times. Then the numbers of the overlapped genes between randomly selected genes sets and genes in modules were used as background.

    Human-specific SNC enrichment analysis

    We evaluated the enrichment of the human-specific single nucleotide changes (SNCs) (determined by inter-species whole genome alignments, downloaded from the http://ftp.ensembl.org/pub/data_files/homo_sapiens/GRCh37/compara/) at the TFs binding motifs. First, we defined the TF set with HSL-binding preference and the TF set without binding preference compared to the conserved loops (using -log10 P Value (H-S - Cons) = 10 and ± 2 as thresholds respectively). Then we calculated the SNC-containing ratio per TFs and compared with the randomly selected regions (TFs with fewer than 5 SNC-containing motif instances were filtered out). The enrichments were evaluated by Fisher’s exact test, and P values were adjusted using the Benjamini & Hochberg method. About 65% (11 out of 17) of these TFs with HSL-binding preference are significantly enriched of the human-specific SNCs (FDR < 0.001).

    TF-target gene regulatory network

    For transcription factors showing differential enrichment between open chromatin regions of HSLs and ConsLs (NFIX, NFIA, NFIC, BHLHA15, TBR1, ATOH1, NR2E3, TCF4, OLIG2, NEUROG1, NEUROG2, EOMES and TGIF1), we predicted their putative target genes and generated TF-gene regulatory networks. First, we calculated Pearson correlation of TF-gene pairs using human fetal brain laminar gene expression data (Miller et al., 2014
    62.
    Miller, J.A. ∙ Ding, S.L. ∙ Sunkin, S.M. ...
    Transcriptional landscape of the prenatal human brain
    Nature. 2014; 508:199-206
    Crossref
    Scopus (550)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) per TF. We selected the genes with the top 1,000 most significant Pearson correlations. Then we filtered out genes of which promoter contains at least one binding site for the corresponding TF. We generated TF-gene regulatory networks using igraph package (V1.2.4). Nodes are TFs and putative target genes, and edges are Pearson correlations.

    3D-DNA FISH imaging and analysis

    Images were acquired by a LEICA TCS SP8 confocal microscope with 63 × objective and 2.5 × Zoom factor. Images were obtained at 1,024 × 1,024 pixels with a scan speed of 600 Hz, frame average with 3, Z size with 0.33 μm and 25 Z-slices were taken. All the images were acquired under the same parameters. Image analysis was performed using imageJ (Schindelin et al., 2012
    80.
    Schindelin, J. ∙ Arganda-Carreras, I. ∙ Frise, E. ...
    Fiji: an open-source platform for biological-image analysis
    Nat. Methods. 2012; 9:676-682
    Crossref
    Scopus (18835)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The centroid positions in xyz were calculated by “3D Object Counter” plug-in with manually curated threshold per channels. Euclidean distances between each channel pairs were calculated.

    Definition of syntenic and non-syntenic 3D genome architectures

    We identified syntenic blocks between human and two other species (mouse and macaque) using Inferring Contiguous Ancestral Regions (inferCars) (Ma et al., 2006
    59.
    Ma, J. ∙ Zhang, L. ∙ Suh, B.B. ...
    Reconstructing contiguous regions of an ancestral genome
    Genome Res. 2006; 16:1557-1565
    Crossref
    Scopus (210)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with the default settings. These blocks represent syntenic genomic regions across-species and the left part of the genome is considered as the non-syntenic regions. If the entire region of a TAD or loop is contained in a syntenic block, we consider it to be syntenic across species. For comparison, we define TADs and loops that span different syntenic blocks or fall in the junction areas of two adjacent syntenic blocks as non-syntenic 3D chromatin features. We also divide the non-syntenic human TADs and loops into 6 categories, including indel, translocation, inversion, large gap, interchromosomal recombination and other type according to the formation mechanisms of the related non-syntenic regions.

    Statistical methods

    All of the statistical details can be found in the figure legend and STAR methods.

    We use cookies which are necessary to make our site work. We may also use additional cookies to analyse, improve and personalise our content and your digital experience. For more information, see our Cookie Policy and the list of Google Ad-Tech Vendors.

    You may choose not to allow some types of cookies. However, blocking some types may impact your experience of our site and the services we are able to offer. See the different category headings below to find out more or change your settings.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
